pros:
This specific job is easy to train

Good hours during holidays

Squad lead treated problems that arose fairly

Competitive wages compared to the higher minimum in other jurisdictions, namely DC
cons:
After seasonal overnight ended, I immediately got 6 AM shifts before I could fix my sleeping schedule, for an entirely different job description than I signed up for.

Indirect supervisors are more aggressive. Among many other things, the higher department manager berated me for what he believed to be sitting aimlessly at times at the very end of overnight shifts, suggesting instead to sweep up possibly the one speck of packaging he saw in the entire warehouse, or to move a stack of ready-to-ship boxes that already gave a wide berth to nearby equipment, purely on the principle of looking busy.

I've been made to set up heavy shelves or move entire lanes worth of product out, only for supervisors to decide arbitrarily to reverse everything.
Advice to Management
1. Changing your mind on a store shelf that you've already directed labor towards breaks backs, wastes time, and demoralizes the worker doing the work. The review went from a 3 to a 2 and half the specific scores went down to 1 just remembering this anecdote.

2. Accept that there can be a point where a worker simply isn't busy, like 5:50 on a shift that ends at 6. Not every shift will be down to the wire, and if it isn't, you've done an especially good job scheduling people, because they were able to finish their work. If someone's resting their bones literally minutes before they would be allowed to clock out, especially overnight, that's your decision that worked out for the better, not someone being lazy.
